Title: Artemisinin-based combination therapy: an illustration of the global pharmaceutical drug market in Asia and Africa

This interdisciplinary research project investigates the global pharmaceutical drug market using Artemisinin-based Combination Therapies (ACTs) as a case study in two African countries (Benin and Ghana) with differing pharmaceutical systems, and conducts a comparison study in Cambodia. The project aims to understand the realities affecting the global drug market in terms of supply and demand, analyze globalizing processes affecting drugs, study public health consequences, compare drug systems, and address the issue of the spread of resistances to ACTs from Asia to Africa.

The project consists of six work packages, including the study of formal and informal pharmaceutical supply, analysis of drug use, scope of ACT consumption, local production and ACT regulations, and an opening into Asia. The project will be managed through WP6, which includes project management, results dissemination, organization of two symposiums, and institutional impacts.

The project's goals are to foster reflection for more efficient pharmaceutical systems in Africa and provide critical information to prevent the spread of resistances to ACTs from Asia to Africa. The project will involve training components, including 8 Master's students, 2 PhD students, and 1 post-doctoral researcher. The project is supported by the PI's skills in methodology and theory, as well as solid partnerships in Benin and Ghana. By combining anthropology, epidemiology, and sociology, this project will provide a comprehensive understanding of the global pharmaceutical drug market and its implications for public health in Africa and Asia.
